ygData.subject: Re: What's the easiest way of getting the original seed in a customized writer?
ygData.msgSnippet: The reason that ARFrontier does not support that is because it was introduced much later than the ARFrontier. The ARFrontier, while an intersting experiment,

The reason that ARFrontier does not support that is because it was
introduc=
ed much later than the ARFrontier. The ARFrontier, while an
intersting expe=
riment, was ultimately abandoned by myself and other
Heritrix developers du=
e to scaling issues mostly. The idea behind it
is still being worked on at =
the Internet Archive and work towards it
will be in the upcoming 2.2 versio=
n and more in 2.4 next year. You
should however expect the ARFrontier itsel=
f to eventually go away
unless someone fights for it and (more importantly)=
 maintains it.

As for your fix, it sounds like it should work.

I'd be ver=
y interested in knowing why/how you are using the ARF if you
can/want to sh=
are?

- Kristinn Sigur=F0sson

> > --- In a=
rchive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Th=
e 'source-tag' is inherited by each discovered URI. So when it
> is set 
> =
> > to be the seed URI, that seed URI appears on all subsequent
URIs. The 
=
> > > immediate-predecessor URI is available as the 'via' URI, which also 
=
> > > appears in the crawl.log.
> > > 
> > > For example, starting with...
=
> > > 
> > > seed:
> > >   uri: http://www.example.com
> > >   hops-path: (=
none)
> > >   via: (none)
> > >   source-tag: http://www.example.com
> > > =

> > > ...you might then discover an clickable outlink (an 'N' hop) in an
>=
 <A> 
> > > HREF attribute...
> > > 
> > > first discovered URI:
> > >   ur=
i: http://www.example.com/subsection
> > >   hops-path: N
> > >   via: http=
://www.example.com
> > >   source-tag: http://www.example.com
> > > 
> > > =
...and then discover an inline image URI (an 'E' hop) in an
<IMG> SRC 
> > =
> attribute...
> > > 
> > > second discovered URI:
> > >   uri: http://www.=
example.com/images/header.gif
> > >   hops-path: NE
> > >   via: http://www=
.example.com/subsection
> > >   source-tag: http://www.example.com
> > > 
>=
 > > So you can construct the graph *as the crawler followed it* from
the 
=
> > > crawl.log, but you can also read the origin-seed and 
> > > immediate=
-predecessor URIs from each line.
> > > 
> > > - Gordon @ IA
> > >

lihoaliho wrote:

url was
extracted

, i need to
> construct

> > > > --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@=
>
wrote:
> > > >> If you set the 'source-tag-seeds' setting of your Frontie=
r to
> > 'true', 
> > > >> each seed URI will be tagged with itself, and th=
en each URI
> > discovered 
> > > >> from those seeds will inherit this sam=
e source seed. This
> source tag 
> > > >> will appear in the second-to-las=
t field of the crawl.log.
> > > >>
> > > >> So, you'll be able to see from =
the crawl.log the seed from
> which any
> > > > URI 
> > > >> was discovere=
d.
> > > >>
> > > >> Note that it's not guaranteed to be the seed from whic=
h the
> shortest 
> > > >> path to the URI can be found -- the crawler some=
times follows
> > > > longer-hop 
> > > >> paths more quickly than shorter-=
hop paths, and the source tag
> > will be 
> > > >> the seed from which the=
 URi was actually discovered.
> > > >>
> > > >> (The above is true for 1.14=
.1; it looks like a bug in 2.0.1 is 
> > > >> preventing the source tag fro=
m appearing in the crawl.log.)
> > > >>
> > > >> - Gordon @ IA
